utterances: No, they tried, and they started a little tunnel, and it just kept going.
So they ended up giving up on that strategy.
And when they got inside, what they discovered was that every room was full nearly to the ceiling, and there were tunnels throughout the house where Langley moved about.
Now Homer had become disabled.
So he was partially paralyzed.
So he stayed in one place, and Langley was the one who collected all this stuff and moved around the house through these tunnels.
And he became somewhat paranoid of people breaking into the house.
So he developed booby traps in the tunnels.

And eventually what happened is that one night, he tripped his own booby trap, and some heavy objects fell on him and crushed him and killed him, and because he was taking care of Homer, Homer eventually died.
Homer - How did Homer die?
Of starvation.
Of starvation, oh, wow.
Tragic doesn't even begin to encompass what's going on here.
I'm Joe Palca and this is SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR News.
So if you need a new bladder, we would take a small piece of your bladder and grow those cells out to make the organ.
But in many cases in the human body, there are cell types that still today, 2007, cannot be grown outside the body in large quantities, and that's where stem cells come in.

And there are very specific cell types that scientists throughout, still can't grow out, such as liver, nerve, pancreas, and these specific cell types, for us to create organs, we would need stem-cell populations.
Are these cells, these amniotic cells, ready for primetime in people yet?
Not at all.
I think, you know, this is still very early in its development stage.
It's going to take a while before we're able to bring these technologies to patients.
And because they come from a person, would they be - would the products of what you make be rejected in someone else?
Well, that's actually another nice advantage of these cells.
The fact is that you can preserve these cells after birth or during birth, if they have an amniocentesis.
But basically, you could preserve these cells for self-use.
So you can just freeze these cells now, and then use these cells if there's ever any problem with that particular patient.
But there's also a second way that you could utilize these cells, and that is by creating a bank of cells that would be available to other patients.
And you would take this from the bank like you would, looking for a match, that you might be a body part, a liver or a kidney or something like that.
That's right.

In fact, what would happen under these circumstances, and this has all been worked in the transplantation field, you would need a bank of approximately 100,000 specimens to be able to provide 99 percent of the U.S.
population with a perfect genetic match for transplantation.
And that would be a lot easier to do with this source of cells, because, as you know, there are approximately 4.5 million births per year in the U.S.

So every birth could be a potential source of stem-cells from the afterbirth, or what we call the placenta, and we could just retrieve those cells, bank those cells and then have those available for other patients when the need arose.
Talking with Dr. Anthony Atala this hour on TALK OF THE NATION: SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR News about his research on stem cells from amniotic fluid.
Dr.

Atala, yesterday, the House, as you know, passed a bill that would increase federal support for embryonic stem-cell research, and opponents are already pointing toward your paper or your research and saying that we don't need to have embryonic stem-cell research anymore, we've got your work that would cover that base.
How do you react to that?
Well, I think it's important to realize that these are not human embryonic stem cells, and they're different cells.
You know, these are different from human embryonic stem cells, these are different from adult stem cells.
And we don't know yet, long term, which cell would be best for what particular application.
So we should continue, you're saying, with embryonic stem-cell research?
Well, I think all research is important because at the end of the day, we just don't know what cell is going to be best for what particular disease process.
So let's talk about where you go from here.
Well, a lot of what we're doing right now is really developing the cells further than we have.
So in this particular publication, we have reported on some of the cells that we are working.
We also have other cell types in the laboratory, and we are expanding the work that we're doing with these cells.
For example, with the nerve cells - we are much more advanced now than when we published the paper.
So we keep working on these technologies further.
When you say advanced, in what way?
Well, for example, we now have even more functionality in terms of these specific cells.
What you're really trying to do with these cells is get them to the point where they function at the same level as the normal cell of that specific type.
So for a nerve cell, you would want that to do all the things that nerve cells do.
For bone, you would want it to do everything that bone does.
So are they actually hooking up and functioning in that sense?
Well, they are actually secreting the things they're supposed to be secreting, and they are hooking up together with each other like they're supposed to do.
Wow, sounds very exciting.
Well, we have a lot of work to do still.
Even though it's exciting, of course, it's still in its early stage of development.
All right, well, thank you of joining us.
I know you've been a very busy guy this week, so thanks again for taking time to be with us.
Pleasure to be with you.
And good luck to you.
Anthony Atala, professor and chair in the department of urology and director of the Institute for Regenerative Medicine at Wake Forest University School of Medicine in Winston-Salem, North Carolina.
Republicans in Congress have introduced a bill to overhaul the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare.
In a moment, we'll hear from the head of Ohio's Hospital Association.
He sees problems with the Affordable Care Act but says this proposal could be far worse.
First, NPR's health correspondent Alison Kodjak joins us with a closer look at what is in this proposal and how people in Washington are reacting to it.
Hi, Alison.
Hi, Ari.
So briefly give us a rundown of what's in the Republican proposal.
Looks like it keeps some of the more popular aspects of Obamacare, like protecting people with pre-existing conditions.
What does it change?
Well, so it's called the American Health Care Act - so change in the name.
And the biggest change is there are no longer mandates for people to buy insurance.
This bill instead tries to lure people into the insurance market using tax credit that people can get ahead of time in, you know, cash essentially and go and buy insurance on the private market.
They have to use them to buy insurance.
They can't buy other things.

She was talking about Norway's butter shortage.

Exactly, and now, even the police departments in their official reports, if they see a residence like this, it's called a Collyer residence.
Really?
So now one of the you mentioned one of them was a piano player.
That was Langley?
That was Langley.
And that reminds me of one detail about what was found in the house.
Do you know what I'm talking about?
Oh yes.
There were 14 grand pianos.
Fourteen grand pianos, unbelievable.
And one of them was a gift from the queen of England.
Really?
Well, I guess the queen probably wishes she hadn't made that gift.

So again, you know, you can see what I'm doing here, and I'm angry at myself for doing it, which is sort of being fascinated and sort of amused by this, even though two people died here from - died from what?
Is it a psychiatric disorder?
Is it obsessive-compulsive disorder?
What is this thing?
Well, this is a very interesting question, especially right now because as we speak, there is consideration for making this a distinct disorder in the new diagnostic code.
And in fact, there that has been the recommendation of the people, myself included, who are doing research on this disorder.
So it looks like it will be considered a separate disorder if that recommendation is accepted.
